as a social studies teacher, i help students sharpen their critical thinking skills by presenting them facts and figures to guide them in forming their own conclusions i don't infiltrate to them my own viewpoints, for it may influence their own views i want my students to form their own opinions and make sure that they are based on facts and empirical evidence this is exactly how lauren greenfield's the kingmaker presented one of history's most divisive topic it is a documentary where you see the camera roll and witness the actions speak for themselves the main subjects themselves, the marcos family mostly imelda marcos are the ones narrating the entire story the camera is basically a fly on the wall real footages and records from the exact events are also shown i've also read that the intended direction of the film depends on how interviews went this means the film does not intentionally gear towards one side of the story only, as both the marcoses side, the victims, and the witnesses were evenly presented the result a compelling story of a true event that almost feels like fiction due to its shocking and unbelievable accounts it makes you wonder why the marcoses agree to be the subject of this documentary and how they feel about this this educational documentary might be a hard watch for some, and i highly advice that the best way to watch this is to have an open mind, without any pre conceived notions about what the show is about now available on vimeo for free with a runtime of 1 hr 40 minutes synopsis this critics' choice usa and warsaw international film festival poland awardee examines the controversial history of filipino politician imelda marcos and her family that gave birth to one of the darkest impositions of martial law in the modern world history

the kingmaker is the story of ruthless and narcissistic imelda marcos, the former first lady of the philippines, and her familys attempts to work their way back into power after her husbands overthrow imelda was the wife of the corrupt ferdinand marcos, who ruled the country between 1965 1986 in interviews she comes across as caring, generous, and eccentric, but the documentary reveals the more sinister aspects of her and her husband's rule in particular the theft of billions from the country and a period of brutal dictatorship involving torture, rape and murder during martial law in the philippines over 3,000 people were killed and 70,000 imprisoned, some for as little as being at a meeting with five or more people activists appear in the film with chilling stories of being tortured and sexually assaulted under the marcos regime the reign of terror lasted until ferdinand was overthrown after trying to rig an election in 1986, ushering in democracy in the country over the protests of some of americas cold war hawks its never clear how involved imelda was in the worst acts of her husbands government, although there are hints in the film that she helped to mastermind the assassination of an opposition leader it is obvious that she benefitted from the record breaking corruption of the marcos regime as a result her habit of handing out wads of money to the poor takes on a sinister air if there is one word to sum up imelda, it is narcissistic throughout the documentary her hunger for popularity goes beyond all reason she sees nothing wrong with importing giraffes and zebras into a country where there are no vets to take care of them, leaving them suffering from skin diseases at one point, she seemingly sincerely says that chairman mao told her that she could end the cold war her accumulation of wealth goes beyond practical levels and seems compulsive her family looted a literally record breaking amount of money and helped to impoverish the philippines for decades, and on a more petty level she was famous for having a collection of over 3,000 shoes you could say that imelda is similar to trump, or alternatively, that trump resembles any number of self deluded dictators throughout history, who tend to be self obsessed in the worst way such characters have an enduring appeal despite their ridiculousness, and as many people in the documentary note, the philippines has been forgiving to strongmen in the past with rodrigo duterte's brutal rule coming to an end and imelda's son bongbong marcos in power in the philippines as of may 2022, the country may unfortunately be on a path to repeating its previous mistakes

the kingmaker begins as an unfettered check in on the life of one of the 20th century's most notorious figures, imelda marcos like a visit to the zoo, we're granted the opportunity to observe the seemingly self delusional marcos in her current habitat as she dreams of a time and place she no longer occupies filmmaker lauren greenfield allows imelda the chance to justify, in her own words, her and her late husband's ruthless and corrupt reign as the authoritarian overlords of the philippines greenfield doesn't assist imelda in her efforts to rewrite history, but she allows imelda to state her case even as the film mixes in interviews from former friends and enemies and victims there are even moments of humor during the film's early going, as imelda's obliviousness to the audience's feeling of disgust toward her wastefully lavish and cartoonish lifestyle, cruel indifference for the rights of her fellow countrymen, and insistence on innocence lands perfectly as a joke at the former filipino first lady's expense however, the film transforms into something far uglier and more frightening as greenfield transitions from mere case study to political expose albeit, one that could be a bit more focused like watching a horror film, the kingmaker turns the joke around on the filipino people and the audience laugh as you might at imelda and her seemingly fantastical defenses of the marcos regime and her pipe dream of seeing her son, bongbong, someday elevated to the presidency, the terrifying and telling reality is that imelda has not yet been relegated to 20th century has been at nearly 90, she's a member of the filipino house of representatives, the mother of an influential filipino senator her daughter and a very possible future president her son , and a behind the scenes benefactor of the current authoritarian leaning president, rodrigo dutarte delusional though she may be, imelda is still as cunningly manipulative as ever hell, she may be once again controlling the strings of power in the philippines, more than 30 years after she and her husband were forced into exile it's the kind of film that sends a chill down your back as the credits roll

beneath the thick make up and perfected smile of imelda marcos there seems to be something more sinister and unnerving about her appearance perception is real and truth is not, she says when speaking about accusations of torture and abuse of power, and it's this understanding of how to manipulate her image that has enabled her to remain outside of a prison cell for so long its a warped form of cognitive dissonance that director lauren greenfield has captured in her documentary, the kingmaker, showing the rise, fall and steady rise again of the marcos clan in the philippines greenfield has spent much of her career documenting the rich and deluded, which made marcos the perfect subject she is famous for her lavish lifestyle which included the ownership of thousands of luxury brand shoes and the spending over 2 billion of state money during her time in power but the longer greenfield spent with imelda, the more obvious it became she was an unreliable narrator, locked away in a fantasy bubble refusing to face up to the pain her family has caused the philippine people for the past half century imelda dominates the first half of the film speaking about her journey to government alongside former husband, and now deceased president, ferdinand marcos at the same time she is galvanising support behind her son, bongbong, while he seeks election as vice president greenfield managed to secure good access to the former first lady with a one on one interview at home, also following her as she travels through the manila slums it never used to be like this she says with faux incredulity handing out cash from the huge wad fixed to her side review continues over at the digital fix

lauren greenfield has made films about people with immense wealth before, and both those and her books tend to cover that uncomfortable collision of aspirational wealth and real lived experiences, about little corners of the human psyche or rather bigger ones in some cases that desire the glossy fashion spread lifestyle imelda marcos largely fits neatly into that, but with a far bigger and more dangerous political footprint that continues to make itself felt ostensibly the title is about her relationship with her husband, the massively corrupt dictator of the philippines for two decades from the mid 60s to the mid 80s at which point he was ousted by a 'people power' revolution via the wife of an assassinated opposition leader, corazon aquino , whose power she was said to manipulate for her own ends, most famously for the acquisition of art, designer items and of course shoes but the film moves quickly on from these trappings to her real and lingering effect on filipino politics, via her family's dynasty and their support for current dictator wannabe rodrigo duterte stylistically it frames marcos with the opulence of her living spaces, repeatedly showing her handing out money to her loyal supporters crowding around her car or in public appearances often held and distributed by her staff she shows off art and photos of her with world leaders at one point hilariously, but utterly unconcernedly, breaking some of these framed highlights while reaching to show off one, i think with her and nixon she is also apparently blithely unaware of how her namedropping comes across, especially when she's talking about aforementioned world leaders or her art collection she could be a figure of fun, but gradually the film becomes more and more serious about her impact, as it layers on the marcos's crimes and the real effects of the policies and division they have sowed within the society, paving the way for her and her family's chilling return to power

really brilliantly constructed the film sets up as a cosy, cute, harmless portrait of an eccentric celebrity in her grey years, and allows itself to remain in that framework as the body count grows higher, as kissinger dances on the screen, as the talking heads, initially brought in to provide sappy reminiscing about imelda's public life, begin to admit propping up dictators for the us' foreign policy interests or detail their sexual assault at the hands of the marcos regime, as the gormless jeb bush like son goes from affable mummy's boy to a brutal example of the violence of capital exerting itself, and of course as it ends with the still unfolding nightmare of duterte the usefulness of this for the film is that it provides an aesthetic critique of the influence of capital on society by relating everything back to marcos, in that we see that all its awful violence, its total control over humanity, its manufacturing of poverty and suffering, don't serve some sort of greater noble cause, but instead simply exist so that an elite can buy shoes and completely bizarre confirmations of their self image it's useful sometimes to remember how utterly ugly it all is, and how power has no correlation to either intelligence or beauty, it just exerts itself in service of itself i'd never immediately disbelieve someone who told me the rich devote their whole lives to worshipping molloch and doing satanic rituals, because there's no need for these things to be real for the idiotic rich to exploit the world in practicing them, as marcos' obsessive world mother fantasy and surreal safari island show the woozy, nightmarish quality of the film's descent into horror doesn't distract from the reality, and it's a serious documentary that isn't reductive to just pointing at the absurdity of the rich instead, it uses these contrasts to make the total dominion of capital in public life and its attendant brutality that protects and asserts the power of the dominant elite all the more vivid, and shows how apparently laughable figures like duterte can exist as the sinew between capitalism and fascism, artificially creating a need and then fulfilling it with a solution that has no alternative or, a failed neoliberal alternative , like marcos literally buying the affection of the poor she helped impoverish it's that clear critique of capital as a structure and empathy for the oppressed throughout that keeps it from being just liberal aesthetic critique, although mockery of the venal rich still has its place don't let unfunny us talk show hosts take it away from you completely

it's women's history month love her or hate her, imelda marcos is definitely a woman who made history in short time i'm going to work my way backwards through documentarian lauren greenfield's filmography, starting with her most recent film, the kingmaker, profiling imelda marcos, the former first lady of the philippines notable for far more than just her epic shoe collection, marcos held the reigns of power behind the scenes during her family's time in office, and now has hopes to return to the presidential mansion greenfield's style in this film is to allow marcos to tell her own history and her own story at first we follow her in person as she is interviewed, talking about her family, upbringing, and rise to power in the mid 1960s for over two decades, her husband ferdinand ruled with her at his side, a political power broker and key agent in diplomacy, using her striking looks and infectious charm to be as close to other world leaders often conservative, often dictatorial as her husband ever was famously catching ferdinand cheating on her with tape recorder under the bed, which she used as blackmail to get what she wanted later, she grew in prestige and influence into the 80s as the family lived like extravagant royalty amidst a nation suffering in abject poverty it was the 1986 people power revolution and election of corazon aquino which forced them from office and exiled the family from ever ruling the philippines again of course, the marcos regime ruled with an iron fist in a military dictatorship, and gradually through the kingmaker the stories of others those affected by the imposition of martial law, the families evicted from their homes to the marcos family could build and renovate at will, the torture victims and political prisoners of innumerable amounts come to the fore, and the real truth is revealed about imelda that is, greenfield allows her to be an unreliable narrator, and brings in members of the aquino family and other opponents to counter her fabrications and exaggerations, like a form of fact checking along with her son bongbong who imelda wishes to see back in the presidential palace again and who probably likes parasite exactly twice as much as you do the two craft a fantastical tale of their birthright to rule, while everyone else fights against their corruption and misdeeds as the loving marcos clan cozies up to current sociopathic president duterte now in her late 80s, imelda appears unrepentant and even in denial of any of her family's actions she still maintains fabulous wealth that was shipped offshore and retained after exile, still flaunting it in the face of today's filipino people and using it to further bongbong's campaign in a bizarre state of denial about the years of horror her family brought to the philippines, imelda plays the victim and twists the facts to beg for sympathy unfortunately it has worked in some ways, stealing billions from the country while many filipinos suffered greenfield has explored themes of wealth, privilege, and bewildering ignorance of power and influence before, and the kingmaker does that effectively the doc plays with a linear timeline a little, and the shifting stories can make it difficult to follow if you don't already have knowledge of the era i imagine anyone not from the philippines and especially anyone under 30 might need more background information about this history to fully grasp the evil of the marcos regime and impact for decades more, as well as how it's profoundly affected the current duterte era this film though is an excellent start added to the best documentary films of 2019 added to lauren greenfield ranked

same power you see in archival footage of the conjugal dictatorship, and the same power that is insinuated as puppetry or at least sponsorship for the currently sitting duterte the nugget quote perception is real and the truth is not is the ironic essence of our time, delivered by the patron saint of filipino boomers herself its a reminder that what seems new and surprising in the valley of fake news, is just what is and what has always been to a certain breed of alligator it should be noted that the docu scopes out a lot of nuance, atrocities and products of her edifice complex in favor experiences are just the tip of the bloody iceberg but understandably, you cant package all nuance into a digestible document, and the target audience is composed of non filipinos but letting them know about the basic stuff is still pretty important but i think the most important thing they gloss over is the corruption and or callousness of what came after it is mentioned, but it couldve used a few more minutes and why a nostalgic rose colored filter has colored many of those who lived through the toppling of the marcoses theres a lot in the docu that many critics of the marcoses already put forward, and a lot that his staunch loyalists deny or recontextualize , and its unlikely to change local perceptions for those who live in the thick of the topic at hand, a different approach to the well, ain't that a 2010 quote if ever there was one the kingmaker is a documentary about the life and times of one imelda marcos, famous first lady of the philippines for 21 years i was generally unaware of her history and her influence going into this, though i'm pretty sure i had an inkling about the shoe thing the kingmaker begins innocently enough, starting with imelda herself she goes through her history, her upbringing, her marriage, and her pride in the political power she had she proclaims herself to be the mother of the nation, a symbol of hope to the masses people love her, she says, and we're given no reason to think otherwise regular documentary viewers may know where this is going we're being lulled into a false sense of security, before the filmmakers blindside us with a right hook and say, no, actually, this is how all that really went down and how it becomes clear as the kingmaker goes on that what we're seeing is a portrait of a raging narcissist, an inconsiderate dictator, and, in all likelihood, a mass murderer the film is directed by lauren greenfield, and while i've not seen any of her previous documentaries, i can tell looking at their descriptions the queen of versailles in 2012, and generation wealth in 2018 that the kingmaker falls right into her wheelhouse of examining and deconstructing the insanity of the rich and powerful right from the start, imelda marcos cuts a fascinating, and infuriating, figure the first thing we see her do in the film is ride around in her luxury limousine, passing by scenes of abject poverty and complaining, this used to be my little paradise in my time, there were no beggars later, we see her handing out giant wads of money to random passersby this is something we see her do a bit, and we come to understand it's a regular occurrence she will frequently walk around, or ride around in busses, handing out money to the impoverished masses, who obviously respond with gratitude that's how she wins their hearts and minds, see the film plays a tricky game with imelda marcos right from the start, we're encouraged to not take her at face value the film highlights the inherently ridiculous nature of her appeals to mass popularity, and her assurance that she's just as powerful and beloved as she was in her prime, when none of that is clearly true imelda marcos begins the kingmaker as a joke, and ends it as a monster as the net of the documentary's eye widens, and more and more talking heads emerge to tell their stories of what it was actually like under marcos dictatorship, the film repeatedly returns to imelda's silent, resilient gaze, and we're forced to ask surely, there's no way you didn't know about this, right after all, you were just bragging about how you were the secret power behind your husband surely, you knew in many ways, the kingmaker is the perfect documentary for our time because imelda marcos is a clown she's a vain, pompous, egotistical fool who at one point insists to the camera that she could've solved all the world's problems, because all the world leaders just found her so charming but behind all that, there's this twisted image of a frilly despot, lounging away as her country starves, and her people are tortured by her the kingmaker i think does an excellent job at painting imelda marcos into a corner from which she can't escape, using cutaway evidence and cross testimony, all while keeping her unaware that this puff documentary is actually a hit piece i appreciate that there's never really a moment that the kingmaker allows her to seem sincere even when the extent to her monstrosity isn't quite apparent, she comes across as a complete egomaniac, with way too much while her country has way too little but then things get serious, fast there are hints as to something darker lurking under the surface early on how she talks about the period of martial law being a golden age, or how she keeps the body of her husband perfectly preserved behind glass, which is just a horrific image those animals are still there, as cross breeding catastrophes we hear about the tunnel of love, which was built by imelda's husband for her, and then became the name of a particularly grisly method of torture and we follow a series of money trails, the end result of which is that the marcos family seems to have been robbing their country blind even more worryingly, the film will frequently cut to the present, where we see imelda masterminding her son's campaign to be vice president of the philippines vice president there is different than in america it's a separate election than that of the president, and the vp generally has more responsibility than they do here , with the money she seems to have stolen directly from the people it's here that the film begins to lose me a little by playing with nonlinear chronology, it sometimes becomes hard to track the exact order of events as they happened and every once in a while, i did find myself wondering, i wonder what was happening in the rest of the world at around this time the image of imelda marcos, now elderly, on the cusp of re achieving political dominance and still in complete denial about her family's evil legacy, is appropriately chilling there are so many things in the past that we should forget

the kingmaker is a 2019 documentary film written and directed by lauren greenfield, featuring the political career of imelda marcos with a focus on the marcos family's efforts to rehabilitate the family's image and to return to political power, including her plans to see her son bongbong become president of the philippines, and the alliance that bongbong and imee marcos established with rodrigo duterte in his bid to win the 2016 philippine presidential election this documentary lays bare the vile nature of the political strategies deployed by the marcos family ferdinand marcos is deservedly portrayed as a fascist capitalist dictator but their greed and lust or power does not stop there after ferdinand dies and is denied a funeral in the philippines, they deploy covert secret strategic tactics to regain power, status and regain their former political reign i was shocked by the fact that the philippine people still believed in the marcos family even after ferdinand marcos had 30 for some unknown reason they still vote for imee marcos, ferdinand's daughter, and later on even for bong bong, ferdinand's son in actuality the marcos family had struck a deal with duterte, a former minister in marcos' government, for the mere purpose of letting duterte become president once duterte becomes president he removes all those who do not agree with marcos' views duterte when inaugurated acts just like his former co conspirator ferdinand marcos and keeps the people in check by oppression similar action are taken against the vice president robredo furthermore, imee has become a senator in the northern region of the philippines duterte, and the marcos family are now working towards having bong bong inaugurated as the new president of the philippines

weathering the storm that is imelda marcos is difficult, deadly even however, lauren greenfield's haunting documentary the kingmaker proves that one can dance with the devil the film examines the lives of the marcos clan from their rise to the philippine government, their downfall, and their eventual return to their current political endeavors to those unfamiliar with their name, the presidency of ferdinand marcos 1965 to 1986 caused some of the worst human rights violations seen in philippine history, not to mention how the oppressive regime plunged the country's economy greenfield wastes no time in depicting the dichotomy between imelda and the everyday filipino citizen its first scene illustrates how emotionless she is when she hands out 50s to the beggars, proceeding to call their area depressing after reflecting on her loss of power this opening scene already sets imelda as someone immaculate, a savior orin her wordsa mother to those who are in need of her love but as the film proceeds, we see how the marcoses were never the loving parents every child wanted their names continue haunt the people who were tortured and killed during martial law the kingmaker beautifully interpolates many sides of those who lived during and beyond the marcos dictatorship it is this multisectoral approach that helps audiences understand how grave the consequences of martial law really are from imelda's friends to opposition figures and martial law victims and activists, no stone is left unturned in dissecting how imelda's brain works what took the cake for me was how these figures were visited a few years after for example, vice president leni robredo and activist may rodriguez' thoughts regarding bongbong marcos' vice presidential run were cut into twothe time leading up to the 2016 elections and the aftermath of robredo's win this follow up emphasizes how the marcoses' dirt will never be erased from history, despite their numerous attempts to do so it feels like the country hasn't moved much in terms of progression what's more haunting is that all the imagery of marcos running feels familiar, scarily real even now that marcos is vouching for president, it is deeply concerning how far their influence can go this is what exactly the kingmaker aims to address to expose the shoes and skeletons of the marcos family's closets and to remind filipinos of their oppressive rule it demonstrates how far one will go to sustain their wealth, power, and image time will tell when the marcos magic will finally disappear from the country but for now, let this film be a reminder to never forget the many lives that suffered under their brutal rule
